results.title: Movietone memories
results.creator_credit: Chris Oliver, Film World, Tru-Vu Pictures and Alec Morgan
results.brief_description: A unique time capsule of our country’s past as captured by the Movietone news crews from the early thirties though to the mid fifties. The headlines, our sporting achivements, the tragedies, and our nation’s often off-beat sense of humour.

results.title: Movies move people
results.brief_description: The world depends on information - films can do a great deal. They can support an idea or change one; they can give an insight into some experience; they can give an inside view of written things; they can be a diagram in motion; film is able to affect attitudes because it affects emotions - it’s a vehicle for the imagination; a method to make thought understood.

results.title: Movies learn to talk
results.creator_credit: Burton Benjamin, Kenco Films, Columbia Broadcasting System and Prudential Insurance Company of America
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Twentieth century”.
Traces the development of sound movies from early experiments with clumsy systems at the turn of the century to “The Jazz Singer” in 1927 and the polished and sophisticated sound film of today. Includes glimpses of film personalities and excerpts from silent and sound movies. Narrated by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Movies in the mill
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin, ONF | NFB and Allen Stark
results.brief_description: Fred Davis discovers how a strip of celluloid becomes a film when he visits a National Film Board production crew on location and the Board’s Ottawa studios. Directors, photographers, film editors, sound technicians, animation artists and many others demonstrate the various elements that go into the making of NFB films. Shows how sound is recorded, film footage is cut and edited to give proper visual balance, the sound track of a film is made also takes a look at the laboratory processes. Photographed by Donald Wilder, edited by Marion Meadows.

results.title: Movies are adventure
results.creator_credit: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Excerpts from old and more recent feature films are used to illustrate how these pictures appeal to every member of the family and enable each to identify himself with the characters on the screen. Offered adventure, a family accepts seats at a theatre - Father becomes the hero of a baseball team, the little boy a cowboy, and mother swoons in Valentino’s arms. The family are ambushed by Indians and freed by stampeding elephants among other adventures.

results.title: Movie stuntmen
results.brief_description: Reveals the skills and courage demanded of motion picture stuntmen and shows how they can perform such stunts as flaming car crashes and leaps from cliffs.

results.title: Movie star cartoons
results.brief_description: A selection of previews and cartoons featuring many famous Hollywood movie stars and entertainers in animation, including Cary Grant, Humphrey Bogart, Greta Garbo, Jack Benny, Lenny Bruce, Amos and Andy and many others. Includes works by directors Friz Freleng and Tex Avery. Entertainment for all the family. Quality is inconsistent due to age and condition of some of the cartoons.

results.title: Movie mad
results.brief_description: Inspired by a hollywood gossip mag, our animated amphibian, “Flip the Frog” apes Chaplin, woos a Manequin, and infiltrates a movie studio to various slapstick ends. Laurel & Hardy appear in parody form. Curious for its use of exagerated gestural style for comic effect. NOTE: This is a silent print of a sound cartoon.

results.title: Movie crazy
results.creator_credit: Harold Lloyd, Harold Lloyd Corporation and Clyde Bruckman
results.brief_description: Lloyd’s alter ego is developed further in this film about a starstruck movie lover who, through a misunderstanding, lands the promise of a screen test. His adventures in Hollywood are predictably punctuated by a myriad of clever sight-gags involving various obstacles and near disasters. Although one of his late films, this is considered the best of Lloyd’s ‘talkies’ with many of its elements having their root in his earlier silent movies. Cast includes: Harold Lloyd, Constance Cummings, Kenneth Thompson, Spencer Charters, Mary Doran. Photography, Walter Lundin ; editing, Bernard Burton.

results.title: Movie-star commercials & important messages
results.brief_description: Assembled here is an amazing and rare collection of commercials and important tv messages made between the 40s to the mid 80s starring some of Hollywood’s greatest actors and actresses. The varying quality of some of the advertisements is due to the rarity of the original film sources and includes commercials that capture great historical moments, for example: Humphrey Bogart promoting Red Cross during during filming on “Casablanca”. John Wayne represents Crosby Shoes in an ad that used the feet of five hanged men to display the shoes. After 72 takes he declared, “noboby’s perfect”. James Dean appears in a community announcement warning of the dangers of fast driving. He prophetically quips upon exiting about the potential of his own death, ironically two weeks before he was killed in a car crash. John Lennon sells ‘peace’ in an amazing ‘bed-in’ manoeuvre not to be forgotten. This collection includes stars (amongst many others) as: Anne Margaret, Buster Keaton, Laurel & Hardy, Groucho Marx, Ronald Reagan, Betty Grable, Elvis Presley, Jack Benny, Richard Burton, Red Skelton, Bob Hope, Dick Van Dyke, Jane Wyman, Marilyn Monroe, the Three Stooges.
